article.name: Cisco Umbrella Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
article.title: Cisco Umbrella Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
article.body:
In this article, you will learn how to integrate Cisco Umbrella with SecurityCoach. Once you set up this integration, data provided by Cisco Umbrella will be available under the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create detection rules for real-time coaching campaigns. For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Tip:SecurityCoach also supports integrating Cisco Umbrella as a Splunk vendor. If your organization uses Splunk for security information and event management, we recommend integrating through Splunk instead by following our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.

Important:You may receive a notification in SecurityCoach to update your Cisco Umbrella configuration with a new API key and API secret. If you receive this notification, you'll need to create a new API key and API secret and then update your existing configuration with these new credentials. For more information, see the Create an API Key and API Secret and Update the Integration in Your KSAT Console sections below.

To set up this integration, you will need access to a Cisco administrator account.

Create an API Key and API Secret

You'll need to create an API key and API secret in your Cisco Umbrella console for this integration. Follow the steps below to create an API key and API secret.

  1. Log into your Cisco Umbrella administrator account.
  2. Navigate to Admin > API Keys.

  3. From the top-right corner of the page, click Add.

  4. Enter a name for your application, such as “SecurityCoachAPIAccess”.

  5. In the Key Scope section, select the Reports option. Then, select Read-Only for the selected scope and resource.

  6. For the Expiry Date, select Never expire.

  7. Click Create Key.

  8. Copy and save the API Key and API Secret somewhere that you can easily access.
    Note:You will need these credentials to complete the process outlined in the Set Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console section of this article below.

  9. Click Accept and Close.

Set Up or Update the Integration in Your KSAT Console

Once you have created your Cisco Umbrella API key and API secret, you can set up the integration in your KSAT console. If you created a new API key and API secret for an existing integration, you can also update your integration in your KSAT console.

To learn how to set up or update your Cisco Umbrella integration, see the subsections below.

Set Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console

To set up the integration in your KSAT console, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  2. Locate Cisco Umbrella and click Configure.
  3. Enter your API Key and API Secret in the corresponding fields.
  4. Click Authorize.

Update the Integration in Your KSAT Console

To update your integration with a new API key and API secret, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  2. Locate Cisco Umbrella and click Edit.
  3. Click Update Registration to update the existing integration.

  4. Update the values in the API Key and API Secret fields.
  5. Click Authorize.

Map Your Users

After you’ve finished integrating Cisco Umbrella, you can map your users either through mapping rules (recommended) or through a CSV file upload. For more information about user mapping, see our Mapping Users in SecurityCoach article.

Once you’ve successfully authorized this integration, you can manage detection rules for Cisco Umbrella on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our Which Detection Rules Can I Use with My Vendors? article.

images.alt:
This is a screenshot of the **Cisco Umbrella** administrative dashboard, titled **Overview**.

**I. Navigation Panel (Left Column):**
The persistent dark gray vertical navigation panel is open, displaying main categories and sub-navigation items, with the **Admin** section expanded.

*   **Main Categories:** Policies, Reporting, Investigate.
*   **Expanded Admin Section (Highlighted in Orange):** The main "Admin" category is selected and expanded.
*   **Admin Sub-Navigation Items:** Accounts, User Roles, Log Management, Authentication, Bypass Users, Bypass Codes, **API Keys (Highlighted in Orange)**, Licensing.

**II. Main Content Area (Overview Dashboard):**
The main panel displays the 'Overview' page.

*   **Header:** Features the Cisco logo, the title "Overview," a hamburger menu icon (collapsed navigation), a **Schedule** button (plus icon), and a time-range selector showing **LAST 24 HOURS**.

*   **Messages Section:** A card displaying key security statistics for the last 24 hours (all showing 0 requests blocked).
    *   **Malware:** 0 requests blocked in the last 24 hours. (Links: View Trends, View Details)
    *   **Botnet:** 0 requests blocked in the last 24 hours. (Links: View Trends, View Details)
    *   **Cryptomining:** 0 requests blocked in the last 24 hours. (Links: View Trends, View Details)

*   **Deployment Health Section:** Displays the status of four deployment metrics using gauge charts (percentages and counts).
    *   **Active Networks:** 0% (0 / 0 Active)
    *   **Active Roaming Clients:** 100% (1 / 1 Active)
    *   **Active Virtual Appliances:** 0% (0 / 0 Active)
    *   **Active Network Tunnels:** No percentage displayed; status text reads "Not tracking data." (Warning icon visible next to text).

This image is a screenshot of the **Cisco Umbrella** administrative console, specifically displaying the **API Keys** management section.

**Header and Navigation:**
*   **Application Context:** The top left features the branding "Cisco Umbrella."
*   **Main Navigation (Left Sidebar):** A dark gray vertical menu includes links such as "Overview," "Deployments," "Policies," "Reporting," "Investigate," and a collapsed "Admin" section showing sub-links "Accounts" and "User Roles."
*   **Page Title:** The main content area title is "API Keys," preceded by the Cisco logo and a hamburger menu icon. An information icon (i) follows the title.

**Content Area:**
*   **Descriptive Text:** Below the title is a gray box containing explanatory text: "Umbrella's API keys are used to authenticate your Umbrella API requests. You can create multiple keys and manage each key's access controls to meet specific use cases. For more information, see Umbrella's Help." The word "Help" is hyperlinked (blue text).
*   **Action Button (Top Right):** A prominent button labeled "**Add**" is located in the top right corner, consisting of a circular blue icon with a white plus sign. This button is used to initiate the creation of a new key.
*   **Key Status Metrics:** Three distinct cards/sections categorize the existing API key types and quantities:
    1.  **API Keys:** Count **0**. (Highlighted with a blue border, indicating the current section).
    2.  **Static Keys:** Count **3**.
    3.  **Legacy Keys:** Count **4**. (Key type name and count are displayed in blue text).
images.context: e top-right corner of the page, click Add.

images.alt:
This image displays a segment of a web UI for generating a new API Key.

**Context and Instructions:**
The primary heading is **Add New API Key**. Beneath the heading, instructional text provides context, prerequisites, and a warning:

> To add this unique API key to Umbrella, select its scope—what it can do—and set an expiry date. The key and secret created here are unique. Deleting, refreshing or modifying this API key may break or interrupt integrations that use this key. For more information, see Umbrella's **Help**.

The word "Help" is styled as a hyperlink.

**Form Element (API Key Naming):**
A required input field for naming the key is displayed (outlined in orange, likely for emphasis in a manual):
*   **Label:** **API Key Name**
*   **Input Field:** A standard text box containing the default placeholder or pre-filled value: **New API Key**.
images.context: ame for your application, such as “SecurityCoachAPIAccess”.

images.alt:
This image displays the configuration screen for adding a new API key within the Umbrella management platform.

**Overall Context:**
The screen is titled **"Add New API Key."** Instructional text advises the user to select scope, set an expiry date, and warns that modifying the key may break integrations.

**UI Elements and Input Fields:**

1.  **API Key Name:** A text input field labeled **"API Key Name"** containing the placeholder or default value **"New API Key."**
2.  **Key Scope Selection (Left Panel):**
    *   Labeled **"Key Scope,"** listing available access categories via checkboxes. A numeric value and an expand/details icon (>) accompany each option.
    *   **Reports** is currently selected (checked checkbox, value **5**).
    *   Other unselected options include **Admin (2)**, **Deployments (10)**, and **Policies (3)**.

3.  **Selected Scopes Configuration (Right Panel):**
    *   The panel title reads **"1 selected."**
    *   A link labeled **"REMOVE ALL"** is available in the upper right.
    *   The selected scope, **Reports**, is displayed in a dedicated configuration row.
    *   This row contains a dropdown menu allowing permission level assignment, currently set to **"Read-Only."**
    *   The scope row also displays the permission count (**5**) and a circular 'X' icon for individual removal.
images.context: strong>Read-Only for the selected scope and resource.

images.alt:
This image displays a UI section for defining an expiration policy, likely for a security key or token.

**UI Elements and State:**

1.  **Section Title:** "Expiry Date" (Bold text).
2.  **Radio Button Group (Expiration Options):**
    *   **Option 1 (Selected):** A radio button labeled "Never expire" is selected (indicated by a solid blue dot). This element is highlighted by an orange rectangular focus/selection indicator.
    *   **Option 2 (Unselected):** A radio button labeled "Expire on:" is unselected (indicated by an empty blue circle).
3.  **Date Input Field:** Associated with the "Expire on:" option is a date picker input field, currently displaying the date "Mar 13 2023". This field includes a calendar icon button (light blue, dotted grid pattern) to trigger a date selection widget.
4.  **Action Buttons (Footer):**
    *   **Cancel Button:** Text link labeled "CANCEL" (uppercase, blue).
    *   **Primary Action Button:** A rectangular, solid blue button labeled "CREATE KEY" (uppercase, white text).

This interface displays newly generated API authentication tokens, structured into three main sections: instructions, credentials display, and a confirmation warning.

**1. Instructions and Context:**
The screen begins with instructional text outlining usage and security constraints:
"Copy the API key and secret and use them to authenticate API requests. This secret is only displayed once. Click Refresh to generate a new key and secret. For more information, see Umbrella's Help." (The word "Help" is a hyperlink.)

**2. Credentials Display (API Key and Secret):**
Credentials are presented in two side-by-side text fields within a bordered container:
*   **API Key:** Labeled "API Key." Contains an obfuscated alphanumeric string in a read-only text field. A blue clipboard icon to the right of the field indicates a Copy functionality.
*   **Key Secret:** Labeled "Key Secret." Contains an obfuscated alphanumeric string in a read-only text field. A blue clipboard icon to the right of the field indicates a Copy functionality.

**3. Security Warning and Confirmation:**
A prominent, mandatory warning bar runs along the bottom of the interface (orange/yellow background with a warning triangle icon):
*   **Warning Text:** "Copy the Key Secret. For security reasons, it is only displayed once. If lost, it cannot be retrieved."
*   **Action Button:** A confirmation button, "ACCEPT AND CLOSE" (blue text), must be clicked by the user to proceed.
images.context: KSAT Console section of this article below.

images.alt:
The image displays a Cisco Umbrella API integration configuration screen within a technical interface.

**Header and Navigation:**
*   The title of the page is **Cisco Umbrella**.
*   In the top right, there is a navigation link labeled **← Back to Integrations**.

**Information Banner:**
*   A light blue banner contains informational text regarding configuration help: "For more information about configuring this vendor integration, click **Configuration Help.**"
*   To the right of the text within the banner is a white button labeled **Configuration Help**.

**Input Fields:**
*   The primary content area features two side-by-side input fields for security credentials:
    1.  Field labeled **API Key**.
    2.  Field labeled **API Secret**.
*   Both fields are currently empty white text boxes.

**Action Buttons:**
*   At the bottom, two action buttons are presented:
    1.  A secondary, outline-style button labeled **Reset**.
    2.  A primary, blue, filled button labeled **Authorize**.

This UI configuration screen manages the integration details for **Cisco Umbrella**.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   The page header displays the integration title: **Cisco Umbrella**, accompanied by a blue status indicator labeled **Active**.
*   A navigation link in the upper right corner reads: **← Back to Integrations**.

**Contextual Banner:**
*   A green contextual banner provides a prompt: "Ready to review your Cisco Umbrella detection rules and create a real-time coaching campaign?"
*   This prompt is paired with a corresponding green action button: **Review Detection Rules**.

**Configuration Fields:**
The primary configuration area contains two input fields for API credentials:
1.  **API Key** (Field contains masked input: `**********`).
2.  **API Secret** (Field contains masked input: `**********`).

**Registration Actions:**
Below the input fields are two primary management controls:
*   A blue button labeled **Update Registration**.
*   A red button labeled **Delete Registration**.
images.context: tration to update the existing integration.

images.alt:
A technical manual description of the image:

The image displays a user interface page titled **"Cisco Umbrella User Mapping"**. The introductory text explains the function: "Map your users by either configuring your mapping rules or uploading a CSV file below. Mapping your users to identifiers links events from this endpoint vendor to specific users." A hyperlink, "Mapping Users in SecurityCoach," is provided for additional information.

The interface uses a tabbed navigation structure:
1.  **Mapping Rules (Recommended)** (Currently active)
2.  **CSV File Upload**

Under the active tab, a section titled **"Configure Mapping Rules"** is displayed. Instructions state: "Configure your mapping rules to map your users to KMSAT user data fields. This is the recommended method for mapping your users."

A single mapping rule is partially defined:
*   `Cisco Umbrella` [Field: `Hostname`] `is` [Dropdown: `Select option`] (Labeled `Knowbe4 User Data Field`).
*   A button labeled **"Add Field"** is present next to the dropdown.
*   A link **"Add Another Rule"** is positioned below the rule definition.

At the bottom of the page, there are two action buttons:
*   **Save** (Primary button, blue)
*   **Delete Integration** (Secondary button, red outline)
